instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin but no boot
threads.message:
Got a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> has green light, fan spins for 10 seconds, goes off, comes back on and ramps up to full speed. No chime present

All rails seem to be present, no water damage to board and no corrosion as far as I can see.

Only odd thing I can see is <TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR>* looks burned?

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is sitting at 8.59v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin but no boot
threads.message:
Do you mean <TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR>?
Remove it and test the board again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin but no boot
threads.message: Yeah sorry meant <TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin but no boot
threads.message:
Please, do NOT quote an entire post visible few centimeters above.
Maintain the forum aesthetic...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin but no boot
threads.message: So remove <TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR> and test the rails again?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin but no boot
threads.message:
Yes, there will not be thunderbolt support anymore.
If board works, then we see later if you want to get thunderbolt working too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin but no boot
threads.message:
The rails all seem to be the same without it attached to board

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8.59v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.417v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> - 3.325v
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 3.323v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.327v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 5.10v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin but no boot
threads.message:
You didn't mention other voltage than <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> before!
We are not sure if "All rails seem to be present" means all voltages are correct.

Do you get 3V at pin 3/<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin but no boot
threads.message:
Sorry should have listed all the voltages at the start

Yeah i've got 3.418v on pin 3 <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>

and 3.327v on <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin but no boot
threads.message:
Did you test for USB activity?

Check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
If all good, try new BIOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin but no boot
threads.message:
Tested all the termination resistors and the traces, all appear to be good

Where would be best to source a new bios? I don't have a donor board to get one off, am I better buying a pre-programmed one or are programmers worth investing in?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin but no boot
threads.message:
Some links should be already posted on the forum, for clean BIOS files.
If you plan to stay in business with Apple boards, get Medusa programmer.

Any other cheap USB programmer can work, but will need to remove/resolder BIOS chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin but no boot
threads.message: replaced the bios chip, still no sign of booting, I still get fan spin but it no longer ramps up to 100% like it was doing before,  voltages are all still the same as before

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin but no boot
threads.message: Should be CPU problem, if the BIOS is good for sure...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin but no boot
threads.message:
Looks like your right, done some more testing tonight, tested all the inputs to the CPU, all measuring fine but still no post

Weird thing is I get usb activity, should you still get usb power if CPU is dead?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin but no boot
threads.message:
USB power and activity is not the same thing!
Do you get steady light on USB mouse if you disconnect/reconnect it when board is turned on?
Still better to test using bootable pendrive with Link LED; if flashes, there is 100% USB activity.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin but no boot
threads.message:
Turns out there is usb activity. Tried 2 different mouse's on it and they both light up

Still a chance the cpu is dead or is that a good sign there's still life?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin but no boot
threads.message:
CPU should be OK, if you confirm USB activity.
I still recommend you to test with macOS pendrive with Link LED; if flashes, is confirmed 100%.

Try PRAM reset.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin but no boot
threads.message:
Probably gonna sound like a stupid question but should there be anything on the usb or does it not make a difference?

It lights up for a brief second when I power on and then goes off. Tried pram reset and no difference

Also not sure if it makes a difference but the original bios chip was a mxic branded chip but the replacement I got was a winbond. Was definitely for the correct Mac though

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin but no boot
threads.message:
So you do NOT have USB activity, as I imagined.
I already told you, do not confuse USB power with activity.
CPU issue probably...
